( It takes 0 ( p ) operations to calculate so we cannot let P become very big without spending an unreasonable amount of time. ) Mo reover,  the terms of the product ( 1.  2 ) corresponding to primes p dividing 6 ( 4.  4 ^ — 27 B ^) are almost certainly the wrong ones ; and it was not then known what the right ones were.  Thus,  even if we had been able to find the value of С for a particular curve Г,  there would have been little prospect of identifying it ; this difficulty has since been removed by the work of Tamagawa [ 23 ]; see § 7 and later on in this introduction.  We hope to return to these direct calculations in a subsequent note. 
For those curves Г which admit complex multiplication an alternative approach is possible ; for in this case it is known that Cr (^) b ® expressed in terms of the Riemann zeta function f ( 5 ) and Hecke L-series.  In particular,  for the curve

In the summer of 1960 we found an approximation to Lj ){ l ) as a multiple of a reasonably rapidly convergent series.  In this way we were able with fair confidence to determine whether I / 2 >( 1 ) vanished or not ; and obtained a good deal of evidence for the conjecture
( 1.  5 ) Lj )( l ) — 0 if and only if g > 0, 
which is a weaker form of conjecture ( A ) above.  However,  when g = 0 we were still not able to calculate Ljy ( i ) accurately enough to be able to interpret it. 
At this point Davenport came to our rescue,  by suggesting that it should be possible to express i > p ( l ) in finite form in terms of division values of the Weierstrass j [?- function defined by the equation
p ' 2 = 4p3 —
The details of this transformation are given in § 3 below.  Exact ( algebraic ) evaluation of the formulae given there in a few simple cases — together with a remark of Kneser that ‘ the answer should be an integer ’ — suggested that
( 1.  6 ) Lj, { i )
2 ) ^ • CO • g ( D ) for i ) > 0, 
(— 4D ) ^• CO • o { D ) for 2 ) < 0, 
where со is the real period of p ( u ) and g { D ) is in general a small positive integer.  We prove in § 4,  by means of class field theory,  that a { D ) is in general a rational integer ; but we can prove nothing about its sign.  Using EDSAC II,  we calculated g [ D ) from these formulae in a large number of cases,  obtaining the results given in Table 1. 
To compare these results with our conjecture ( 1.  5 ) we needed to be able to find the corresponding values of g.  For large 2 ) the methods of our previous paper proved too slow and we had to use a method tailored to our special curve ( 1.  3 ). This is described in § 5 : we do not regard it as novel,  but have to describe it at length in the absence of any satisfactory reference.  All the results we have obtained are compatible with ( 1.  5 ); but there are many curves for which we were not able to find the value of g. 
The rest of this paper is concerned with the interpretation of the integer o ( D ) when it does not vanish.  We hoped from the beginning that this would turn out to be
